properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A surge of arctic air is expected to bring colder temperatures to most of Alberta today. This arctic air will begin to push eastwards into southwestern Alberta later this afternoon and help to generate a prolonged period of snowfall. The snow will continue through Wednesday and into Thursday morning. Total snowfall amounts will be from 20 to 30 cm with some localities seeing 50 or more before the snow ends on Thursday. At this time, the likely areas to see this snow will be in the Crowsnest Pass and Cardston regions but there is a risk for some higher snowfall into the Claresholm and Lethbridge regions as well. This special weather statement will likely be replaced by a snowfall warning later today. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-27T03:24:52-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-26T11:25:52-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1568582737.2019

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and freezing rain is expected Wednesday. Snow with risk of freezing rain is expected to develop Wednesday morning and continue into Wednesday evening. The precipitation may also change over to rain Wednesday afternoon. Several hours of freezing rain are possible. Total snowfall amounts of 2 to 4 cm are also expected. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-27T11:50:05-00:00

Area: South River - Burk's Falls
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Cold and Blustery Week Ahead A transition to colder conditions will begin today across northern and central British Columbia. The cold air will persist through the end of the week with temperatures in the -15 to -25 range. Blustery northerly winds will accompany the arrival of the Arctic air with windchill becoming a factor tonight and Wednesday. However, the Arctic air over the interior will deepen and temperatures will continue to drop Thursday and Friday. People working and spending time outside are reminded to dress warmly and in layers, preferably with a wind-resistant outer layer. Travellers are encouraged to add winter emergency kits to their vehicles which include a blanket, extra clothes and boots. For more cold weather preparedness tips, visit: https://www.canada.ca/en/environment-climate-change/services/seasonal-weather-hazards/be-prepared-for-winter.html#toc5 ### Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-27T03:23:44-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-26T11:24:44-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3326067071.2019
Area: Highway 97 - Clinton to 100 Mile House via Begbie Summit, Highway 97 - Pine Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow possible Thursday. Total snowfall: 5 to 15 cm. Locations: southern New Brunswick Time span: late Wednesday night into Thursday afternoon. Remarks: Snow is expected to begin late Wednesday night and continue into Thursday afternoon. Snow could become mixed with rain later Thursday morning and into the afternoon, which could reduce snowfall accumulations in some areas. Snowfall amounts of 5 to 10 cm are generally expected but could reach near 15 cm over higher terrain. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-27T11:37:08-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-26T19:38:08-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4021135777.2019

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A significant snowfall is expected Wednesday. Snow is expected to develop Wednesday morning and continue into Wednesday evening. The snow may be mixed with or change to rain Wednesday afternoon. There is also the risk of freezing rain during the change from rain to snow. Total snowfall amounts near 15 cm are expected for areas north of Lake Nipissing, particularly from Temiscaming to Marten River Provincial Park. Significantly lesser snowfall amounts of 2 to 4 cm are expected for areas south of Lake Nipissing where mostly rain is expected. The snow and freezing rain are the result of a low pressure system moving over Lake Huron and Georgian Bay late Wednesday. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-27T08:12:54-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-26T16:13:54-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3985040209.2019
Area: West Nipissing - French River, North Bay - Powassan - Mattawa
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong southwesterly wind gusts are expected Wednesday. Strong southwesterly winds gusting 70 to 80 km/h are expected to develop late Wednesday morning or early Wednesday afternoon and persist into the evening. There is also the possibility of stronger wind gusts near 90 km/h in the afternoon. Winds will slowly ease Wednesday evening. Strong winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Power outages are also possible. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-27T11:56:54-00:00

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow with risk of freezing rain is expected Wednesday. A developing low pressure system over Colorado is expected to track over Lake Huron and Georgian Bay late Wednesday. Snow is expected to develop Wednesday morning and continue into Wednesday evening. The snow may be mixed with rain Wednesday afternoon. There is also the risk of freezing rain. Total snowfall amounts near 15 cm are possible, especially from Temiscaming to Marten River Provincial Park. Total snowfall amounts of 5 to 10 cm are likely near Lake Nipissing. There remains some uncertainty regarding the exact track of this system. This statement may be upgraded to a snowfall or freezing rain warning as the track of this low becomes more certain. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-27T02:12:43-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Cold and Blustery Week Ahead A transition to colder conditions will begin today across central British Columbia. Arctic air will reach the coast by Wednesday night. Temperatures will dip below the freezing mark for most coastal communities. Blustery outflow winds will accompany the arrival of the Arctic air yielding cold wind chill values. The Arctic air will deepen throughout the week supporting temperatures and wind chill values down to the -5 to -10 range. People working and spending time outside are reminded to dress warmly and in layers, preferably with a wind-resistant outer layer. Travellers are encouraged to add winter emergency kits to their vehicles which include a blanket, extra clothes and boots. For more cold weather preparedness tips, visit: https://www.canada.ca/en/environment-climate-change/services/seasonal-weather-hazards/be-prepared-for-winter.html#toc5 ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-27T03:24:57-00:00

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Strong southerly winds will develop over Paulatuk late this afternoon. These winds are expected to combine with loose snow cover to produce blizzard conditions. The blizzard conditions will end on Wednesday morning when the winds diminish. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.

properties.Summary:

Those travelling between communities should be on the lookout for localized flooding, minor washouts from runoff, and water pooling, especially in areas with higher existing snowpack. Some areas further inland and over higher elevations may also experience accumulating wet snow. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Update: High Water Advisory Alert Is Being Issued For The Roseau River From Gardenton To Dominion City
properties.Summary:
Description: Update: This is a Manitoba Emergency Alert. Manitoba Infrastructure's Hydrologic Forecast Centre has issued a High Water Advisory for the Roseau River from Gardenton to Dominion City due to expected high flows. If you are in the affected area, be watchful of local waterways as flooding is likely to occur. Do not attempt to cross fast flowing waters or waters of unknown depth. Avoid flooded areas. Follow all directions by the local authorities. Listen for updates and take all necessary precautions to stay safe. Up-to-date information is available at www.gov.mb.ca/flooding and www.manitoba511.ca or stay tuned to local media.
Expires: 2019-11-27T11:30:00-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization, 2019-11-26T12:03:13-06:00, 5778FAFE-199F-2925-8578-F4221A5FE178
Area: Roseau River from Gardenton to Dominion City
properties.Author: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. An arctic ridge of high pressure over the BC interior will intensify this evening. Strong northeasterly outflow winds up to 70 km/h gusting to 90 will develop this evening for the Southern Gulf Islands and overnight for Howe Sound and Greater Victoria. The strong winds will ease Wednesday night. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 20 cm is expected. Heavy snow has developed in local areas of the Kananaskis and Okotoks regions. Snow at times heavy will continue today and tonight. Amounts of 10 to 20 cm are expected with locally higher amounts to 50 cm over higher elevations. Heavy snow will taper off on Wednesday. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
